China ( Hainan Islands, Beibu Gulf, Nansha Islands) to Vietnam and Philippines .

Although Taylor and Wells (1994) synonymised
C. kawamurai
with
Cheungbeia mindanensis ( Smith, 1877 )
, the latter ( holotype , Figure 2H ) has a smoother appearance,
C. kawamurai
having coarser spiral sculpture, which forms low but distinct nodules where the spiral cords cross the axial ribs; the subsutural concavity is also deeper in
kawamurai
. A third member of this complex,
Cheungbeia laterculata ( Sowerby 1870 )
( holotype , Figure 2I ), differs from both
mindanensis
and
kawamurai
in being (typically) strongly striped with dark brown or black, and in its stronger spiral ridges (which cross the intervals between the axial ribs), whose interstices bear a distinct spiral microsculpture, lacking in the other two species;
C. laterculata
also attains a larger size and has a more prominently alate outer lip.
